children.markdown:
[The Long View](https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2016/12/19/edward-burtynskys-epic-landscapes) — sparse but effective use of multimedia elements, as you might expect from *The New Yorker*.

[Lessons from Hurricane Harvey](https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2017/11/11/climate/houston-flooding-climate.html) — nice uses of galleries and interactives

[Everything Water Touches](https://www.newyorker.com/news/news-desk/the-fear-of-water-in-flint)

[M29 – Berlins Buslinie der großen Unterschiede](https://interaktiv.morgenpost.de/m29/) – A really complete interactive mix, You need to speak German to really appreciate it, though.

[Rise of the MegaFarm](https://www.thebureauinvestigates.com/stories/2017-07-17/megafarms-uk-intensive-farming-meat%20) — nice example of a simpler multimedia feature from the Bureau of Investigative Journalism

[How to Fix a Toilet](http://how-to-fix-a-toilet.com) — Better than it sounds. Honest.

metadata.title: Shrinking cities - Stories from China’s former boomtowns
metadata.description: China is well known for its megacities, and we’re used to thinking of the country’s urban areas in the context of growth, but is that the whole story?
metadata.author: Sixth Tone

metadata.title: Life after slavery
metadata.description: Three survivors, three countries, three struggles. Follow the journeys of Nasima, Mbarka and Moises in #LifeAfterSlavery http://news.trust.org/shorthand/life-after-slavery/ via @TRF_Stories

metadata.title: The end of our innocence
metadata.description: A Stuff special report on the Christchurch mosque shootings
metadata.author: Stuff

metadata.title: Fifty years on, the Aberfan disaster told by the people who were there
metadata.description: Many are telling their stories publicly for the first time.

metadata.title: How China Turned a City Into a Prison
metadata.description: Children are interrogated. Neighbors become informants. Mosques are monitored. Cameras are everywhere.
metadata.author: Chris Buckley
metadata.publisher: The New York Times World The New York Times World

metadata.title: Reading Boris Johnson’s mind: unique analysis reveals what the PM really thinks
metadata.description: We know what politicians say in soundbites and speeches, but it can be harder to know what they really think, and more importantly what they used to think before they reached high office. In Boris...
metadata.author: Daniel Clark, Interactive Journalist | Matt Chorley, Red Box Editor | Sam Joiner, Interactives Editor

metadata.title: How Does the Human Soul Survive Atrocity?
metadata.description: After the horror of ISIS captivity, tens of thousands of Iraqis — many of them children — are caught up in a mental-health crisis unlike any in the world.
metadata.author: Jennifer Percy

metadata.title: How Scientology doubled its downtown Clearwater footprint in 3 years
metadata.description: The mysterious deals could reshape downtown Clearwater.
metadata.author: TRACEY McMANUS

metadata.title: Thirty Years of Game Boy
metadata.description: We celebrate the Game Boy’s 30th anniversary with Andy Robertson

children.caption: Work done by a former City student.

metadata.title: A closer look at the ravaged Notre Dame Cathedral
metadata.description: The fire at the Notre Dame Cathedral damaged its roof and spire, but some of its treasures survived. Here’s an up-close look.

metadata.title: Manchester Arena bombing: The agonising missed chances to stop a killer
metadata.description: A devastating breakdown of the countless errors and near misses before, during and after the 2017 attack, and whether 22 deaths could have been prevented

metadata.title: How Singapore built one of the world’s biggest floating solar farms
metadata.description: The Sembcorp Tengeh Floating Solar Farm spans 45 ha - or the size of 45 football fields - and is one of the world’s largest inland floating solar photovoltaic systems. Constructed on the surface of Tengeh Reservoir, the system’s 122,000 solar panels will soon help power Singapore’s clean energy ambi…
metadata.author: Alexis Gabrielle

metadata.title: The climate disaster is here – this is what the future looks like
metadata.description: Earth is already becoming unlivable. Will governments act to stop this disaster from getting worse?
metadata.author: Oliver Milman, Andrew Witherspoon, Rita Liu, and Alvin Chang
